newsitem.title: INDIA: India committee to consider foreign media entry.
newsitem.headline: India committee to consider foreign media entry.

text.p: The Indian government plans to appoint a committee to help it consider whether foreign newspapers should be allowed to publish in India, a senior official said on Wednesday.

N. Mohanty, a top-level Industry Ministry official, told Reuters after a news conference on foreign investment that Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's cabinet has asked the Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) to prepare a status paper on all aspects of the media.
"The panel will come up with concrete proposals for foreign investments in (India's) media," Mohanty said.
Last week India rejected a proposal by Britain's Pearson plc, publisher of the Financial Times, to acquire an equity stake in an Indian newspaper company.
The move was in line with India's long-standing practice of barring foreign journals from publishing in the country.
The decision to turn down Pearson was taken after pressure from a few publishers, while several editors, journalists and even a number of publishers supported the plan, Mohanty said.
Foreign newspapers and journals are freely imported into India, but they cannot publish Indian editions.

Asked if the committee would consider the entry of foreign investments in the print media, Mohanty said: "Today, I can subscribe to foreign newspapers published abroad, so why can't we have them here?"
The committee will have members from the FIPB and will study various investment options in both electronic media, including radio and television, and print media, he said.
Mohanty said he could not say when the committee would be set up.
Pearson's proposal to acquire a stake in India's Business Standard Ltd won the approval of the FIPB but was shot down by the Cabinet Committee on Foreign Investment (CCFI).

The FIPB approval has touched off a heated debate over foreign media entry in India. Communists in the 13-party United Front of Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda joined opposition Hindu nationalists in criticising the approval.
